title: SVG file making gtk-based applications to crash
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Unzip this archive: [Starry_dusk_on_Matterhorn.svg.zip](/uploads/82b85ea65742c5d97caeb65d722151f9/Starry_dusk_on_Matterhorn.svg.zip)
 2. With Thunar or Nautilus, open the folder containing the extracted SVG file.
 3. Click on the file.

The browser crashes.

## Version information

 - Which version of GTK you are using: 3.24.8
 - What operating system and version: Xubuntu 19.04 64-bit

## Backtrace

See these two backtraces:

 - Thunar: [bt-thunar.txt](/uploads/c8951f39f6c4bee2fd6aa752c917537d/bt-thunar.txt)
 - Nautilus: [bt-nautilus.txt](/uploads/8ccc539da5ae68bc3519249c0ce01faf/bt-nautilus.txt)

## More information

- Initially reported on the Thunar bugtracker: https://bugzilla.xfce.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15797
- Source of the SVG file: https://forum.kde.org/viewtopic.php?f=312&t=160623#p416780

title: GtkHeaderBar rightclick on element in headerbar focuses the item, causing left somewhere else activate that item
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Open Nautilus, Gnome-settings, etc. (hope this is really gtk related)
 2. Rightclick an item in the Header bar (for example the menu), this brings up the generic menu in Gnome Shell/Mutter
 3. Left click somewhere else in header bar to cancel it
 4. Repeat the left click and the widget we previously rightclicked on will be activated

Tested in GTK Demo as well

## Current behavior
The item gets activated

## Expected outcome
The item should not be activated

## Version information
Fedora 30
Gnome Shell 3.32.2
gtk3.x86_64                                                            3.24.10-1.fc30                                             @updates                 

## Additional information
![video](/uploads/7aa0f145795e7d4a14a73f0f2744ad39/video.webm)

title: Drag big size images from browser to file managers failed.
description:
## Steps to reproduce

1. open an image in browser.  (firefox or chrome)
2. drag it to file mananger. (nautilus or nemo or caja)
3. auto save (normal) or nothing happend (issues/bug)

## Current behavior

I test in firefox / chrome.

Drag images to nautilus / nemo / caja.

Big image all failed.

**small image works**

image url: http://corkartstheatre.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Harbour_Image.jpg

![small_image_works](/uploads/7c1864e8712bfc486805c05ac0c7e1b6/small_image_works.gif)

**big image failed**

image url: http://pic.lvmama.com/uploads/pc/place2/2016-09-14/9aab9bb7-2593-4ca6-8c5a-31355443aebc.jpg

![big_image_not_works](/uploads/54a6eedea17cb8429854f2dc437b0aa3/big_image_not_works.gif)

## Version information



|  | version |
| -------- | ------------ |
| gtk2     | 2.24.32      |
| gtk3     | 3.24.10      |
| chrome   | 76.0.3809.87 |
| firefox  | 68.0.1       |
| nautilus | 3.32.1       |
| nemo     | 4.2.2        |
| caja     | 1.22.1       |

## Additional information

I'm not sure what cause this happend. 

I was wondering if nautilus / nemo / caja all failed. 

And they all gtk apps. 

So i opened this issues. Hope it can help.

title: Allow adding bind properties without bind-property set in ui file
description:
It would be nice if one could avoid specifying `bind-property` in ui file, which would assume that the source property (ie, `name`) and target property are the same.

Eg:
```xml
<child>
  <object class="GtkLabel">
    <property name="label" translatable="yes">Apply</property>
    <property name="visible" bind-source="apply_button" />
  </object>
</child>
```

title: gtk_application_set_accels_for_action ignores "<Primary>" within accels
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Use `gtk_application_set_accels_for_action` to set the shortcuts for an action, e.g. Ctrl+q
 2. Note that the accel is used without the `<Primary>` modifier if used, e.g. 'q' instead of 'Ctrl+q'

Example code:

```c
static void
app_startup (GApplication *app) {
  AppPrivate *priv;
  GtkStyleProvider *provider;

  mainApplication = APP (app);
  priv = mainApplication->priv;

  g_action_map_add_action_entries (G_ACTION_MAP (app),
                                   app_entries,
                                   G_N_ELEMENTS (app_entries),
                                   app);

  const gchar *quit_accels[2] = { "<Primary>q", NULL };

  gtk_application_set_accels_for_action (GTK_APPLICATION (app), "app.quit", quit_accels);

  G_APPLICATION_CLASS (app_parent_class)->startup (app);
}
```

## Current behavior
<!--
  Please describe the current behaviour
-->

The action is run only if the `<Primary>` key is unused, not with it

## Expected outcome
<!--
  Please describe the expected outcome
-->

The action is run only when the `<Primary>` key is held in addition to the other keys

## Version information
<!--
 - Which version of GTK you are using
 - What operating system and version
  - For Linux, which distribution
 - If you built GTK yourself, the list of options used to configure the build
-->
Version: 3.24 (from master org.gnome.Sdk)

OS: org.gnome.Sdk//master

title: Proximity events only emitted on main window, no callback on subwidgets possible
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Register callbacks by using `g_signal_connect` and listen for `proximity-in-events`.

## Current behavior
Proximity events are routed to top widget (i.e. main window). If a signal on a sub widget is connected the callback does not get triggered. This also happens when nobody else is listening for those events.

## Expected outcome
Correctly relay proximity events to corresponding widget.

## Version information
3.24.10 Arch Linux

## Additional information
Might be related to #2070

title: There's no way to leave a GtkComboBoxText field using the keyboard if it has the can_focus property enabled
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Open any GTK+ dialog that has a combo box
 2. Use arrow keys or tab/shift+tab to navigate between fields, focus the combo box field
 3. Try to use arrow keys or tab/shift+tab to navigate between fields

## Current behavior
The combo box remains selected; up/down arrors change the selection, left/right arrows do nothing, tab/shift+tab do nothing

## Expected outcome
I can use tab/shift+tab to continue navigating between fields.

## Version information
GTK 3.24.8 on Ubuntu 19.04

## Additional information

title: About dialog animation is often sluggish
description: In about dialogs, the animation sliding the "Contributors" text view is heavy and often loses frames even on relatively powerful systems, especially on Xorg. While it is indeed a very nice and intuitive animation (though the only occurrence in the whole GNOME environment), it would be better at least to optimize this or "sliding widget animations" as a whole (e.g. by inhibiting redraw until the animation is over)

title: gsk: Use supersampling for subpixel positioning
description:
Currently, we upload glyphs to the texture at the device resolution, rendered shifted by their subpixel position. And then we  place the texture aligned to the pixel grid. Since we use a 4x4 subpixel grid, we end up with  up to 16 different renderings of the same glyph.

Another strategy I'd like to try is to render the glyphs at the subpixel resolution (ie 4x more pixel in both directions), and then use supersampling in the shader to get the pixel-resolution rendering, placing the texture at the subpixel position.

Relevant links:

- https://community.khronos.org/t/multisample-textures/69065/7
- https://community.khronos.org/t/sampler2dms-and-texelfetch/60196/2

As a side benefit, this should let us unify the handling of hi-dpi and subpixel positioning.

title: Enter/Leave notifies of same physical device have different GdkInputSource
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Use Wayland.

 1. Move active stylus into widget (or into proximity)
 2. Move active stylus out of widget (or out of proximity)

## Current behavior
Currently, if I move my stylus into the widget area a correct `GDK_ENTER_NOTIFY` is generated. You can get `vendor_id` and `product_id` without any issues and source device type is `GDK_SOURCE_PEN`. As the stylus leaves the widget a `GDK_LEAVE_NOTIFY` is emitted but this time the source device type is `GDK_SOURCE_MOUSE`. This seems to be caused by the device being a `GDK_DEVICE_TYPE_MASTER` on leaving whereas on entering it is correctly set to `GDK_DEVICE_TYPE_SLAVE`.

## Expected outcome
Emit both events as `GDK_SOURCE_PEN`.

## Version information
GTK 3.24.10 on Arch Linux

The relevant file might be gdkdevice-wayland.c. If sb can help me to setup a debugging environment (preferably in CLion) I might be able to fix this myself.

title: Children of Gtk.Expander can sometimes be dragged even when the Expander is collapsed
description:
## Steps to reproduce:
Example Widget Tree:
Gtk.Box -> Gtk.Expander -> Gtk.ListBox -> Gtk.ListBoxRow(s) -> Gtk.EventBox

1) Expand the Gtk.Expander
2) Collapse the Gtk.Expander
3) Hide and then show its parent Gtk.Box
4) It's now possible to drag its children as if the Gtk.Expander was expanded

## Version information
GTK 3.24.8

Ubuntu 19.04

## Additional information
Screen Recording: https://gfycat.com/ellipticalchillyairedale

Example Code (Python): https://gitlab.gnome.org/snippets/819

title: Right-click on CSD titlebar buttons leaves them :active
description:
Doesn't seem to happen on X11, or xwayland at least.

I guess this is happening because we set the :active state in `gtkmain.c` directly and then never unset it?

title: GtkMenuButton does not work for all old menubutton use cases
description:
1) There is not way to create the popover the menubutton is supposed to show on the fly, i.e. only when the button is clicked. There is no `clicked` signal anymore which could be used for this purpose in the past. This is important when e.g. every listbox row is supposed to have a menubutton with a popover, but only one of those popovers can be visible at a time anyway.
2) There is no way to set a custom child of the menubutton. There's private API for this in `gtkmenubutton.c` already as far as I can see.

title: Popover clicks propagated to volume-/scalebutton
description: Just try the one in the widget-factory

title: Tooltips from popovers wrong positioned and stacked
description:
I don't think we have a ready made reproducer but it's simple enough to write one.
The tooltips are positioned wrong and stacked behind the popover they originate from.

Edit: There is a simple reproducer now: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/commit/20d7b7f59b501c3989c0c01958b013f9d74c2b88

title: Popovers inherit parent widget CSS style
description:
Not a bug per-se of course, since that's normal. But in the popover case it just looks wrong. Same for popover-based context menus of course.

![foo](/uploads/910e244a6f1b3602490c7fbb9919d8ba/foo.png)

title: Warning shown when clicking menu button
description:
When menu button is clicked, the following warning is shown:

```
(gtk-builder-tool:21132): Gtk-WARNING **: 08:04:40.620: Child name 'main' not found in GtkStack
Gtk-Message: 08:04:40.622: Ignoring an unexpected focus event from GDK on a non-toplevel surface.
```

The ui file tested: [main.ui](/uploads/310a2a691d688d8cc9d74eb57a886fce/main.ui)

title: GtkFileChooser search very often incorrectly returns no results
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Open a file chooser
 2. Start searching for existing files or folders
 3. Repeat with different query lengths

## Additional informations

It's probably easier to reproduce with disabled animations. Happens with tracker enabled and disabled.


## Version information

Arch Linux
gtk 3.24.10

## Screencast
[GtkFileChooser](/uploads/32de205f81e0cf90c907481a5b841c65/GtkFileChooser.mp4)

title: GTK3 on Windows takes a long time to start up (in update_keymap)
description:
The `gtk_init` function takes around 600 ms to execute, adding to a noticeable lag when starting up a GTK3 application. Almost all of this 600 ms is spent inside `update_keymap` in gdk/win23/gdkkeys-win32.c.

Worthy of note is that I currently have 4 keyboard layouts active due to the work I did previously. Glancing at it, the runtime of `update_keymap` appears to be linear in the number of keyboard layouts, so if you only have one – most common case – it's probably not as noticeable. But I think even 150 ms is a lot.

title: segfault in g_type_check_instance_is_a () at /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgobject-2.0.so.0
description:
Hi developers,

As a developer of claws-mail I have been struggling with a mysterious segfault which caused claws-mail to crash. A backtrace from gdb when the segfaults occurs is as follows:

```

    (private=0, expected=0, futex_word=0xa631e0)
```

I can provided a complete log from valgrind when the segfaults occurs but since this log file is 111 MB big I will only send it on request.

Command used when running valgrind:
```
$ G_SLICE=always-malloc G_DEBUG=gc-friendly valgrind \
  --tool=memcheck --error-limit=no --leak-check=full \
  --show-reachable=yes claws-mail 2>&1 | tee valgrind.log
```

name: In progress
description: An issue that is currently being worked on

name: Review ready
description: An issue that is waiting for review

name: Stretch
description: Long term vision for the project. Approximately a four releases moving target.

name: Windows
description: Related to Win32 GDK backend or to GTK working on Windows operating system
